qas.question: USB  was designed for peripherals to be what?

answers.text: closely associated with a host computer
isolation between the networked device (computer, phone, etc.) and the network cable up to 1500 V AC or 2250 V DC for 60 seconds

context: Ethernet standards require electrical <a2_0>isolation between the networked device (computer, phone, etc.) and the network cable up to 1500 V AC or 2250 V DC for 60 seconds<a2_0/>. USB has no such requirement as it was designed for peripherals <a0_0>closely associated with a host computer<a0_0/>, and in fact it connects <a1_0>the peripheral and host grounds<a1_0/>. This gives Ethernet a significant safety advantage over USB with peripherals such as cable and DSL modems connected to external wiring that can assume hazardous voltages under certain fault conditions.
